    28→        "raw_content": "Week 3THEORIES OF ABNORMALITYGPC 415 –Fall 2025-2026Dr. Selin Ayasayas@metu.edu.tr QUESTIONuYou were asked to interview a client. uWhat information is essential?uWhat is the plan you should follow to explain his concerns? Why do we need theories?uRoad map. Tells us where to look, how to start, which methods of treatment to use.uAllows us to make educated guesses uAllows us to explore these possible explanations empirically CASE: JORGEuWhat kind of influences can be considered?uTry to identify emotional, cognitive, behavioral and social influences that can contribute to the concern of Jorge. uSome possible areas to intervene (might be hypothetical)? CASE: JorgeuJorge is 14 years old. He is referred to you because of academic concerns. He has been performing below average in classes, cannot concentrate and too quite and nervous. His reading abilities are below his grade-level. His parents and teachers are angry with him for not making an effort. uJorge says: “it’s the teachers, how am I expected to learn when they yell at me! The think I am dumb. I know I don’t have the necessary brain for it and I am a bit slow. Even thinking about school makes me nervous. I am afraid I’ll say something stupid and they’ll laugh at me!”uParents perspective: His parents are Spanish speaking moved from an English speaking neighborhood when he was 8. He struggled to learn the language quickly which made parents frustrated. They think he has learning disabilities because he cannot focus. The think he blames teachers and should be placed in a special classroom and maybe given medications to calm his worries down. CASE: JORGEuBiological/Neurodevelopmental: Learning difficulty? Attention problems?uPsychological: Parents attitude? teachers attitude, temperament, anxietyuEnvironmental: Language change, moving Integrative approachuJorge had many environmental, psychological influences. uHow do we attempt to make sense of the many environmental and individual factors that influence child behavior? Integrative approach uNo single theoretical orientation can explain various behaviors or disorders, we must be familiar with many theories and conceptual models. TheoriesuBiological approachuPsychodynamicuBehavioraluCognitive uHumanisticuFamily-systems BIOPSYCHOSOCIAL APPROACH Biological factors (e.g. genes)Social factors (e.g. upbringing)Psychological factors (e.g. poor skills, cognitions) Biological trigger (onset of a diseaseSocial trigger (e.g. major lossPsychological trigger (e.g. perceived loss of control) DIATHESISSTRESS PSYCHOANALYTIC APPROACHuAll behavior , thoughts, and emotions are influenced to a large extend by unconscious processes.uUnsolved conscious conflicts mostly rooted in early childhood. Aim is to try to make them conscious or pre-conscious.uExamine internal forces that motivate behavior.uAbnormality: conflict between unconscious urges and conscious desires. PSYCHOANALYTICuBasic drives that motivate human behavior: Life (Eros) & Death (Thanatos) instinct. uEros: procreation, social cooperation, survival.uThanatos: Aggression, risky behavior, relieving trauma.uEnergy from these drives constantly seeks to be released but can be channeled by different psychological systems. uThese drives are inherent and often in conflict with each other. PSYCHOANALYTICuId: pleasure principle. Maximize pleasure minimize pain as soon as possible.uEgo: Develops from id as child grows older. Seeks to gratify our wishes and needs in ways that remain within the rules of society. uSuperego: Develops from ego a little later in childhood. Rules and regulations, morel standards we internalize. Psychosexual stagesuOral: First 18 months. Libidinal impulses are best satisfied via mouth area.uAnal: Until 3 years old. Fixed here, can be too harsh, stubborn, controlling.uPhallic: 3 to 6 years. Pleasure is genitals. uLatency: Attention turns to developmental skills and socialization. MethoduFree associationuDream analysisuResistanceuTransferenceuWorking through and over BEHAVIORAL APPROACHuFocuses on the influences of reinforcements, behavioral consequences and punishments in producing behavior and personality.uDo not believe in biological determinism: they do not see personality traits as inborn BEHAVIORAL APPROACHuStimulus -responseuClassical conditioninguOperant conditioninguModeling & observational learninguExtinction Some examples:uFood aversion after chemotherapy.uAlcohol and drug addictions. uA cue that signals the “drug is coming soon”uTaking the drug in a new place without the familiar cues.uOverdose MethoduBehavioral assessmentuBehavior change techniquesuRemoval of reinforcements, token economies, time out, cueing, modeling & observational learning. uSystematic desensitizationuHierarchyuRelaxation techniquesuHabituation Areas of useuPhobiasuBehaviorism in educationuSpecial educationuClassroom management uIn Ms. Rivera’s 5th-grade classroom, students frequently talk during independent work time, making it difficult for others to concentrate. Despite repeated verbal reminders, the noise level remains high, and Ms. Rivera realizes she needs a more structured approach to manage the behavior effectively. uTo address this issue, she applies behaviorist strategies focused on reinforcement and consequence. She introduces a “Quiet Stars” system where the class earns a star for every 15 minutes of quiet, focused work. After collecting five stars, students receive a 10-minute free activity period on Friday. Ms. Rivera provides immediate verbal praise to students demonstrating desired behavior and uses calm reminders when the noise begins to rise. If the class becomes too noisy, she erases a star as a mild punishment. Over time, students begin to associate quiet work with positive outcomes, leading to a more focused and cooperative classroom environment. Critique of theories so faruStrengthsand weaknesses of each approach?BiopsychosocialPsychodynamicBehavioral BREAK COGNITIVE APPROACHuOur thoughts, beliefs shape our behaviors and emotions.uCausal attribution (the answer to why) can effect our emotions and self concept.uAutomatic thoughts, Intermediate beliefs, core beliefs.uGlobal assumptions: “I should be loved by everyone” COGNITIVE BIASESuMinimisationuMaximisationuSelective abstractionuAll or nothing thinkinguAwfulizingu…uThey blocks people from achieving goals and purposes.uCreates extreme emotions which distresses and immobilizes. BECK’s cognitive triadWorldEveryone is against me because I am worthless SelfI am worthless and inadequate FutureI’ll never be good at anything uAfter not being invited to a group study session, Ecestarts thinking, “People don’t really like me”(negative view of self). She then tells herself, “Everyone only cares about their own friends; people are generally unfriendly”(negative view of the world). Finally, she concludes, “Things will always be like this; I’ll never have close friends”(negative view of the future). Ellis’ ABC MODEL Activating eventBeliefs about the event Effective new beliefsDisputations to challenge irrational beliefs Consequence ABCDEuAfter receiving a low grade on her psychology exam, Ayşe feels deeply upset and starts thinking she might not be smart enough to succeed in the course. She avoids studying for the next exam and considers giving up on the subject altogether, feeling anxious and discouraged whenever it’s mentioned. uA –Activating Event:Ayşe receives a low grade on her psychology exam.uB –Belief:She thinks, “I’m not smart enough; I’ll never succeed in this subject.”uC –Consequence:She feels anxious and discouraged, avoids studying, and considers giving up.uD –Disputation:Ayşe challenges her belief by asking, “Is it true that one bad grade means I’m not capable? Could there be another explanation?”uE –Effect (New Belief):She adopts a more rational belief: “I didn’t do well this time, but I can improve with better study strategies,” leading to greater motivation and confidence. METHODuOften combination –CBTuCognitive restructuringuReframinguGuided discovery uJournaling and thought records uBehavioral experimentsuAim: to challenge irrational and dysfunctional thought processes. To break the circle of maladaptive thinking, feelings and behavior. Humanistic ApproachuHumans have an innate capacity for goodness and for living a full life. uConflict? Pressure from society to conform to certain norms rather than to seek ones most developed self. uEnvironment can play a strong role in our happiness.uHow does Rogers describe the ideal environment that a person will naturally grow? Humanistic ApproachuDue to stress and pressure of society and family, people can develop rigid and distorted perspectives of the self.uDistinction between perceived self vs the ideal self -incongruenceuThis conflict leads to emotional distress, unhealthy behaviors and even loss of touch with reality. METHODuClient centered therapy. Principles also found in gestalt therapy and existential therapyuAim: Help clients discover the greatest potential through self-exploration. Therapist provides optimal conditions for the client to flourish. uUnconditional positive regard, reflection, empathy, free will, congruence Case of SarauSara, a 28-year-old marketing professional, seeks therapy for chronic anxiety. She experiences constant worry about her performance at work, fears being judged by colleagues, and often feels tense, restless, and fatigued. She reports avoiding social interactions and struggling to make decisions due to fear of failure. uAccording to Carl Rogers, psychological disorders like anxiety occur when there is a mismatch between a person’s real self and ideal self(incongruence). In Sara’s case, she has internalized messages from her family and workplace that she must be perfect and meet others’ expectations. Because she feels she cannot meet these conditions of worth, she experiences chronic tension, self-doubt, and anxiety. Her true feelings and needsare suppressed, and she experiences inner conflict between who she really is and who she feels she should be.uIn short, Rogers would say Sara’s anxiety is not caused by external events alone, but by incongruence between her self-concept and her experiences, which prevents her from accepting herself fully and acting in accordance with her authentic values. Family-Systems ApproachesuFamily as a complex interpersonal system, with its own hierarchy and rules that govern family members’ behavior. uSystem either functions well and supports members wellbeing or dysfunctional and creating and maintaining psychopathology.uPsychological disorder is not a problem within the individual but indication of dysfunctional family system. Family-systems approachesuFamily cohesiveness, adaptability to change and communication style. uInflexible familyuEnmeshed familyuDisengaged familyuA pathological triangular relationship: Parents avoid discussing by involving children. METHODuYou cannot help an individual without treating the entire family system.uTarget: Family communication, problem solving, rehearsal of skills and role playing.uDifferentiation of self.uFamily emotion & projection process. Case of MarkuMark, a 15-year-old high school student, has begun skipping classes, arguing with teachers, and getting into minor fights with peers. His teachers notice a sudden drop in his grades and report frequent disruptive behavior. At home, his parents are often in conflict, frequently arguing about finances and parenting, and they have inconsistent rules and expectations for him. Mark seems withdrawn at times but also acts out, creating tension in the household. uFrom the perspective of family systems theory, Mark’s behavior is seen as a reflection of the family’s dysfunctional patternsrather than solely an individual problem. His acting out serves as a signal of imbalance within the family system, highlighting unresolved conflicts, inconsistent boundaries, and role struggles. Interventions would focus on addressing family interactions, improving communication, and clarifying rolesrather than targeting Mark’s behavior in isolation. The theory emphasizes that change in one family member affects the entire system. Critique of theories so far?uStrengths and weaknesses of each approach?CognitiveHumanisticFamily-Systems QUESTIONS? COMMENTS? SEE YOU NEXT WEEK!"

    38→        "raw_content": "Somatic Symptoms and Dissociative DisordersGPC 415 –Fall 2025-2026Selin Ayas Somatic symptom & Dissociative DisordersuBoth attributed to similar process: Patients cannot confront difficult emotions and stressful experiences, so they unconsciously convert their emotions into physical and psychological symptoms. uPeople with these disorders may experience significant physical symptoms for which there is no apparent organic cause. uThey are often excessively concerned about their symptoms and spend a great deal of time worrying and seeking medical treatment. Difficulty DiagnosinguThe possibility that the individual has a real physical disorder. uAttributing to nervousness and attention seeking. Raises trust issues. uEasy to distinguish example:uWhen a child is perfectly healthy on weekends but has stomachaches in the morning just before going to school, it is possible that the stomachaches are due to distress over going to school. DSMuSomatic symptom disorder uIllness anxiety disorder uFunctional neurological symptom disorder (hypochondriasis)uFactitious disorder uRelated: Psychological factors affecting other medical disorders* *people having an actual illness that is worsened by psychological factors. (e.g. Cancer , diabetes). Topic of health psychology. Somatic Symptom Disorder uExperiencing one or more distressing physical symptoms and spends a great deal of time and energy thinking about these symptoms and seeking medical care for them.upain in different locations of the body, ufatigue, uheart palpitations, ugastrointestinal symptoms,ulimb weakness. uHealth concerns persist even when they have evidence that they are well. Illness Anxiety Disorder uHypochondriasis. Very similar to somatic symptom disorder. uThe primary distinction between the two disorders is that people with somatic symptom disorder actually experience physical symptoms and seek help for them, uwhereas people with illness anxiety disorder worry that they will develop or have a serious illness but do not always experience severe physical symptoms. uThe core feature of illness anxiety disorder is the cycle of worry and reassurance-seeking behaviors about health concerns, as opposed to a focus on relief of distress caused by somatic symptoms. Illness Anxiety Disorder uIf a physical sign is present, it is typically a normal physical sensation. People with this disorder have no physical illness, but they are overly preoccupied with the beliefthat a serious illness is present whichadversely affects their daily life.uFocus on the meaning of illness, or physical symptom.uPeople with illness anxiety disorder tend to misinterpret normal body sensations as a sign of a serious illness which causes significant distress and the tendency to seek immediate medical care.uEating a lot, feeling really full, having a heartburn but worrying about stomach cancer. Somatic Symptom vs. Illness anxietyuPeople with somatic symptom disorder are more likely than people with illness anxiety disorder to report more severe healthanxiety, somaticsymptoms, depression, panic disorder and higher health service use. uPeople with somatic symptom disorder tend to experience bodily sensations more intensely than other people, to pay more attention than others to physical symptoms and health-related information, and to catastrophize these symptoms uDeniz is a 24-year-old graduate student who reports intermittent chest tightness, shortness of breath, and occasional dizziness over the past year. The physical sensations are usually mild and brief but occur unpredictably.uDeniz has visited multiple physicians and emergency departments, particularly after noticing bodily sensations that “feel different than usual.” Cardiac and pulmonary evaluations have consistently been normal. Deniz spends several hours a day monitoring bodily sensations and researching serious illnesses online.uWhen asked about the symptoms themselves, Deniz states,u“The sensations are uncomfortable, but what scares me is what they might mean.”uDeniz avoids intense physical activity, fearing it could trigger a serious medical event. Between episodes, Deniz reports relatively normal functioning but remains preoccupied with the possibility of having an undiagnosed life-threatening illness. uSSD or IlnessAnxiety? Choose one and defend it. uDeniz reports that the chest discomfort is present almost daily and has caused them to stop attending classes.” uDoes your diagnosis change? Why or why not? uThe difference between SSD and IAD is notwhether symptoms exist,but what dominates the person’s mental life: the symptom or the feared disease. uAt the beginning:→“What if this means something deadly?”(IAD)uAfter the twist:→“These symptoms are controlling my life.”(SSD) uSame person, same body —but the diagnosis may change.Because psychopathology is not about quantity, it’s about patterns Theories & Causes uCognitive factors play a strong role uDysfunctional beliefs about illness, often assuming that serious illnesses are common, and tendency to misinterpret any physical change in themselves as a sign for concern. uThey believe they are vulnerable to a wide range of physical illnesses and unable to tolerate pain. Theorıies& CausesuSomatic symptoms for which no sufficient physical causes are found, are frequently reported among those with PTSD, regardless of the traumatic event. uIndividuals with a history of sexual, domestic or psychological abuse reported high levels of disabling chronic painand somatic symptoms. TreatmentuCould be hard to convince people for psychological treatment as they strongly believe the causes are physical. uPsychodynamic therapies focus on providing insight into the connections between emotions and physical symptoms by helping people recall events and memories that may have triggered their symptoms. Treatment uBehavioral therapies attempt to determine the reinforcements individuals receive for their symptoms and health complaints and to eliminate these reinforcements while increasing positive rewards for healthy behavior. uCognitive therapies for these disorders help people learn to interpret their physical symptoms appropriately and to avoid catastrophizing them, similar to the cognitive treatment of panic symptoms Case -Emma Emma is a 28-year-old woman who has been preoccupied with the fear of having a serious illness for the past two years. She frequently interprets normal bodily sensations (mild chest tightness, headaches, fatigue) as signs of life-threatening conditions. She checks her body multiple times a day, searches symptoms online for hours, and asks her partner for frequent reassurance. Medical evaluations have repeatedly come back normal, yet she finds it hard to trust the results. Her health anxiety has caused concentration difficulties at work and withdrawal from social activities. uDiagnosis -ArzuuABC analysis -ZişanuTreatment goals -CerenuCognitive interventions -ÖzgeuBehavioral interventions -SelinuTherapists’ stance -Basma Treatment Plan Treatment GoalsuReduce illness-related preoccupation and catastrophic misinterpretations.uDecrease reassurance-seeking, body checking, and excessive online searching.uIncrease tolerance of uncertainty about health.uImprove daily functioning and engagement in life activities. Psychoeducation uExplain the Health Anxiety Cycleusing Emma’s patterns:Sensation →Catastrophic thought (“heart disease”) →Anxiety →Checking/Googling →Temporary relief →Stronger cycle. Treatment PlanCognitive InterventionsuIdentify & Challenge Maladaptive ThoughtsuExample from case:“This chest tightness means something is seriously wrong.”uExamine evidence, alternative explanations (stress, posture, fatigue).uProbability & Consequence ReassessmentuWork with Emma on realistic risk estimates.uContrast medical reassurance vs. catastrophic predictions.uIntolerance of Uncertainty WorkuExplore Emma’s need for certainty (“I must be 100% sure I am healthy”).uIntroduce balanced statements: “I can live with some uncertainty and still be safe.” Behavioral InterventionsuBehavioral ExperimentsuDelayed doctor consultation trial (e.g., wait 48 hours before acting on a symptom).u“No Googling” experiment for 24–48 hours.uExposure & Response PreventionuMaking a hierarchy of health related thingsuReduce checking behaviors:uLimit body-checking to once daily →every other day →none.uLimit reassurance-seeking:u“Reassurance-free periods” (2 hours →half day →full day” Therapists’ StanceuValidate symptoms as real, not dangerousuAvoid medical reassurance collusionuWatch for:uChronic healthcare utilizationuTherapist becoming reassurance sourceuIdentity consolidation around illness Conversion Disorder uCore FeatureOne or more neurological symptoms(e.g., weakness, paralysis, seizures, sensory loss)Incompatible with known neurological or medical conditions Symptoms are not intentionally produceduCommon PresentationsuMotor: paralysis, tremor , gait abnormalitiesuSensory: blindness, anesthesia, deafnessuSeizure-like episodes (non-epileptic seizures)uSpeech disturbances Conversion Disorder uOne particularly dramatic conversion symptom is glove anesthesia, in which people lose all feeling in one hand, as if they were wearing a glove that wiped out physical sensation. uTypically involves one specific symptom, such as blindness or paralysis, but a person can have repeated episodes of conversion involving different parts of the body. Theories uConversion symptoms are the result of the transfer of the psychic energy attached to repressed emotions or memories to physical symptoms. The symptoms often symbolized the specific concerns or memories being repressed. uThe role conversion symptoms play in alleviating distress by removing the individual from difficult environments and allowing him or her to avoid unwanted responsibilities or situations. These symptoms of conversion disorder as a learned maladaptive behavior that is reinforced by the environment Add one symptomuAn adult reports physical symptoms that worsen during stress uAn adult reports physical symptoms that worsen during stressuThe person reports feeling constantly on edge and overwhelmed uAn adult reports physical symptoms that worsen during stressuThe person reports feeling constantly on edge and overwhelmeduThey report persistent bodily discomfort and fatigue uAn adult reports physical symptoms that worsen during stressuThe person reports feeling constantly on edge and overwhelmeduThey report persistent bodily discomfort and fatigueuThey frequently monitor bodily sensations and worry something serious is wrong uAn adult reports physical symptoms that worsen during stressuThe person reports feeling constantly on edge and overwhelmeduThey report persistent bodily discomfort and fatigueuThey frequently monitor bodily sensations and worry something serious is wronguEmotional needs are difficult to express and are often felt in the body instead uAn adult reports physical symptoms that worsen during stressuThe person reports feeling constantly on edge and overwhelmeduThey report persistent bodily discomfort and fatigueuThey frequently monitor bodily sensations and worry something serious is wronguEmotional needs are difficult to express and are often felt in the body insteaduDuring an argument, the person suddenly loses the ability to speak for several hours uAn adult reports physical symptoms that worsen during stressuThe person reports feeling constantly on edge and overwhelmeduThey report persistent bodily discomfort and fatigueuThey frequently monitor bodily sensations and worry something serious is wronguEmotional needs are difficult to express and are often felt in the body insteaduDuring an argument, the person suddenly loses the ability to speak for several hoursuNeurological evaluation shows no structural abnormality and symptoms fluctuate inconsistently. uNotice how tempting labels areuEverything up to slide 5 was meaningful —but not diagnostic Psychodynamic InterventionsuExploration of Affect Behind SymptomsuHelp Daniel link flare-ups with emotional triggers.uExample intervention:“You mentioned the pain increased after the argument with your supervisor… I wonder what feelings came up that might have been difficult to express.”uEncourage naming emotions rather than describing sensations. uAddressing Maladaptive Relational PatternsuExplore caregiving dynamics (fear of burdening others, need for validation).uExamine transference: Does the patient expect the therapist to rescue, minimize, or dismiss their discomfort?uWork through dependency and autonomy themes. Psychodynamic InterventionsuInterpretation of DefensesuCommon defenses in SSD: somatization, repression, minimization, displacement.uIdentify how bodily complaints defend against experiencing affect.uExample:“I notice when we talk about your frustration with your partner, you shift quickly to describing the discomfort in your stomach.” uStrengthening Mentalization and SymbolizationuTeach Daniel to see symptoms as signalsrather than evidence of damage.uIncrease ability to hold both mind and body in awareness (mentalization).uEncourage symbolic thinking:“What might this tension be saying about what you’re carrying emotionally?” uYou have learned the interventions.Now answer: What is the therapist actually responsible for? uEliminating symptoms ?uExplaining the exact psychological cause ?uConvincing the patient ? uYou have learned the interventions.Now answer: What is the therapist actually responsible for? uEliminating symptoms ?uExplaining the exact psychological cause ?uConvincing the patient ? uIf the symptoms do not improve quickly, what does that mean about the therapist Translate into…uEliminating symptoms uExplaining the exact psychological cause uConvincing the patient uHelping the patient feel safeuHelping the body function againuPreventing harm caused by treatmentuTolerating not having all the answers Treatment –Conversion DisorderuIn conversion disorder, improvement is not a measure of therapist competence u“I know your symptoms are real. We don’t need to fully understand them yet to help your body regain function.” uIn conversion disorder, techniques open the door —but the therapist’s stance determines whether the nervous system feels safe enough to change. Factitious Disorder uFactitious disorder is commonly referred to as Munchhausen’s syndrome. uPeople with factitious disorders fabricate, simulate, or exaggerate the symptoms of a physical or mental illness through a variety of deceptive methodsfor the purpose of gaining attention. uFactitious disorder differs from somatic symptom disorder in that factitious disorder involves evidence that the individual is providing false information or behaving deceptively. uFactitious disorder differs from malingering, by motivation to fake symptoms. uMalingering: fake a symptom or a disorder in order to avoid an unwanted situation, such as military service, or in order to gain something, such as drugs or money. Not a psychological disorder.uFactitious disorder: the symptoms are intentionally created to gain attention. Factitious DisorderuFactitious disorder imposed on self: a person deliberately fakes an illness specifically to gain medical attention in order to become a patient. ucontaminating a urine sample with blood to manipulate a laboratory test, ingest a substance to create an abnormal test result uFactitious disorder imposed on another (formerly referred to as factitious disorder by proxy) is diagnosed when an individual falsifies illness in another (e.g., child, pet, older adult). uparents fake or even create illnesses in their children in order to gain attention for themselves. They act as devoted and long-suffering protectors of their children, drawing praise for their dedicated nursing. Their children are subjected to unnecessary and often dangerous medical procedures and may actually die from their parents’ attempts to make them ill. SSD, IAD, Malingering or Factitious?u“Symptoms are intentionally produced or falsified”u“External gain is present”u“Primary goal is to assume the sick role”u“Symptoms are not consciously produced”u“Medical tests are manipulated”u“Distress is genuine but misinterpreted” SSD, IAD, Malingering or Factitious?u“Symptoms are intentionally produced or falsified” -Factitiousu“External gain is present” -Malingeringu“Primary goal is to assume the sick role” -Factitiousu“Symptoms are not consciously produced” –SSD/IADu“Medical tests are manipulated” -Factitiousu“Distress is genuine but misinterpreted” –SSD/IAD TreatmentuThe patient intentionally produces or feigns symptoms.uInsight is usually low.uHelp-seeking is driven by psychological needs(e.g., to be cared for), not secondary gain.uGoal is harm reduction—not confrontation or cure.Therapeutic stance is collaborative, non-judgmental, and focused on maintaining treatment contact. Treatment GoalsuReduce unnecessary medical procedures and hospitalizationsuImprove emotional regulation and interpersonal functioninguEnhance insight into stressors driving symptom productionuBuild alternative, healthier ways of meeting relational needsuMaintain a stable therapeutic relationship u!! Therapeutic Alliance is central. What would you do next?uYou have been seeing Lena (32)in outpatient psychotherapy for 6 weeks, following repeated hospitalizations for unexplained medical complaints. A shared care plan is in place with her physician to reduce unnecessary testing.uOver the past five years, she has been treated at multiple hospitals for recurrent infections, fainting episodes, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Her medical records show extensive testing and several invasive procedures, all with inconsistent or inconclusive results. Clinicians note that symptoms often worsen shortly before discharge and improve when she is closely monitored. She appears highly knowledgeable about medical terminology and expresses strong interest in test results and procedures. She denies any intentional symptom production and becomes distressed when doctors suggest reducing further testing. There is no clear external incentive such as financial compensation or legal benefit. uI went to the ER again last night. They said my tests were normal,but I know something is seriously wrong. I need you to help me convince them to run more tests.” uShe looks anxious but also animated while describing the hospital visit.She asks you to write a notesupporting further medical evaluation. uAcknowledge distress without colludingu“I can see how frightening this feels for you.”u2. Set a clear, calm boundaryu“I can’t support additional tests right now, because our goal is to reduce medical harm.”u3. Redirect to function and safetyu“Let’s focus on how these hospital visits are affecting you.” What would you do next?u“If you won’t help me, maybe I shouldn’t come here anymore.” uAcknowledge + Stay Presentu“It sounds like you’re feeling very disappointed and maybe alone right now.”uRestate Commitment Without Collusionu“I want to keep working with you, even when I can’t do what you’re asking.”uReaffirm Boundary Clearlyu“I won’t support more medical testing, but I will support you in staying safe and functioning.”uNormalize the Ruptureu“Moments like this can feel like rejection —they’re important for us to talk about.” Therapists RoleTherapist’s role is to:uPrioritize patient safetyuSet firm but non-punitive limitsuReduce unnecessary medical interventionsuMaintain a calm, neutral stanceuCoordinate closely with medical teams uAccuse the patient of lyinguAttempt to “expose” deceptionuConfront intent directlyuProvide excessive reassurance or tests Therapist should NOT: Dissociative Disorders uDissociation is not the problem, it is the solution the nervous system found.uA group of disorders characterized by a disruption in the integration of:uconsciousnessumemoryuidentityuperceptionuemotionuDissociation involves a disconnection between mental processes that are normally integrateduSymptoms are involuntary and not intentionally produced Dissociative Disorders uOccurs when the nervous system is overwhelmeduAllows psychological survival when escape is not possibleuReduces emotional and physical painuProtects the individual from unbearable experiencesuOften develops in response to chronic or early traumauBecomes automatic over timeuCan persist even when danger is no longer present Dissociative Identity Disorder uFormerly; Multiple personality disorder uPresence of two or more distinct identities or personality states in an individual uIdentities create a pronounced discontinuity uin the sense of self, ufeelings of control over actions, affect, consciousness, and memory in the individual Alters & alternate identities uEach has their own first-person perspective or experience of self-consciousness, memories, and their own sense of agency and will. uIndividuals often report being unaware of other identities or report amnesia for experiences that occurred when other identities were in control of the host identity uOne way amnesia is also possible in some cases one alter is aware of what the other is doing. uMemory gaps Alters & alternate identities uAlters can take different forms and serve specific functionsuCommon alter types include:uchildupersecutoruhelper / protectoruopposite-genderumemory-holding altersusuicidal alters Alters & alternate ıdentıtıesChild AltersuThe most common type of alteruTypically remain the same age over timeuStrongly associated with childhood traumauOften hold traumatic memoriesuMay emerge to experience or contain traumauWhen in control, behavior and speech may appear childlike Protector (Helper) AltersuFunction: protect the system from harmuMay appear strong, calm, or controllinguOften manage daily life or crisis situationsuCan block access to traumatic memories Persecutor AltersuFunction: maintain control through self-criticism or punishmentuMay be harsh, self-blaming, or aggressiveuOften internalize abusive voicesuTheir behavior is protective in origin Suicidal AltersuExpress urges for self-harm or suicideuOften hold intense despair or hopelessnessuSignal high levels of distress within the systemuRequire careful risk assessment and safety planning Causes & TheoriesuOne basic assumption is that alters emerge due to an unsuccessful attempt of the child to process psychological trauma. The alters are the result of the child’s inability to develop and maintain a unified sense of self since identity is still maturing within the individual.uMeaning, as a result of psychological trauma, the dissociations within the individual occur at the level of identity during a period of critical development that leads to fragmentation. uA very significant number of people with DID report a history of abuse, when a child is exposed to a chaotic and dysfunctional environment, coercion, and overt severe physical and/or sexual abuse. Theories uMany theorists who study DID view it as the result of coping strategies used by persons faced with intolerable trauma—most often childhood sexual and/or physical abuse—that they are powerless to escape uThe little girl being sexually abused at nights imagines that the abuse is happening to someone else, as a way to distance herself from the overwhelming emotions she is experiencing. She may float up to the ceiling and watch the abuse in a detached fashion. Now not only is the abuse not happening to her, but she blocks it out of her mind—that other little girl remembers it, not the original self. In this model, DID is an internal divide-and-conquer strategy in which intolerable knowledge and feeling is split up into manageable compartments. These compartments are personified and take on a life of their own. theoriesuPsychosocial explanations of DID include developmental traumatization and sociocognitiveconditions, biological factors include trauma-generated neurobiological responses. Meaning, psychological trauma impacts brain function that can directly relate to DID symptoms. uNo direct examination of genetics has occurred in DID. Tendency to dissociate is substantially affected by genetics. treatmentuThe goal of treatment is integrating all the alter identity into one coherent sense of selfin which the client is able to develop the capacity for coping with distress and trusting healthy relationships. Not to eliminate the different alters but to have them co-exist in a coordinated way.uAchieved by “giving voice” to each identity uHelping the identities become aware of one another, uDetermining the function or role of each personality, uHelping each personality confront and work through the traumas that led to the disorder and the concerns each one has or represents, uNegotiating with the personalities for unification into one personality who has learned adaptive styles of coping with stress. Treatment uA three--phase,trauma-focused psychotherapy process uIn the first stage, clinicians focus on safety issues, stabilize DID symptoms, and establish a therapeutic alliance. Failure to stabilize the patient or a premature focus on traumatic memories can result in deterioration in functioning and a diminished sense of safety. uIn the second stage oftreatment, following the ability to regulate affect and manage their symptoms, patients begin processing, grieving, and resolvingtrauma. uIn the third stage oftreatment, patients integrate dissociated self-states and become more socially engaged. Dissociative Amnesie& fugueuInability to recall important autobiographical informationuMemory loss is not due to substance use or medical conditionuOften follows severe stress or traumauInvoluntary and not intentionally produceduCan involve confusion about personal historyuDistress or functional impairment is present Dissociative amnesiauPrimary feature is memory lossuNo purposeful traveluPerson usually remains in familiar surroundingsuIdentity is generally preserveduAmnesia may be localized, selective, or generalized Dissociative fugueuA subtype of dissociative amnesiauInvolves sudden, unexpected traveluPossible partial or complete identity lossuMay assume a new identity temporarilyuOften appears organized and purposeful during travel Treatment D. Fuge& AmnesiauTreatment GoalsuRestore missing autobiographical memory (as appropriate and tolerated)uIncrease psychological stability and reduce distressuImprove grounding, emotional regulation, and coping skillsuProcess underlying trauma or stressorsuReduce risk of future fugue episodesuStrengthen identity continuity and daily functioning Establishing Stability and SafetyuObjectives:uEnsure the patient is medically stable after fugue/state confusionuReduce acute anxiety, depression, and disorientationuCreate a predictable therapeutic environmentuInterventions:uPsychoeducation on dissociationuSafety planning (for fugue risk, wandering, or impulsive behaviors)uGrounding techniques: sensory grounding, orientation exercises, breathinguEmotion regulation skills (DBT-informed)uSleep and routine stabilizationuInvolve family/supports to increase safety and structure GroundinguSensory Groundingu5–4–3–2–1 techniqueuNaming colors or objects in the roomuHolding a textured or cold objectuPhysical GroundinguFeet firmly on the flooruPressing hands togetheruNoticing contact with chair or grounduOrientation GroundinguSaying name, age, date, and locationuReminding oneself: “I am safe right now”uLooking around and naming where you are Grounding brings the person back to the present, it does not process the trauma. Depersonalization/derealization disorder uAltered sense of reality or detachmentuExperiences feel strange or unrealuInsight is preserved (reality testing intact)uOften triggered by stress or anxietyuMemory and identity remain intactuSymptoms can be transient or persistent Depersonalization/DerealizationDepersonalizationuDetachment from one’s self or bodyuFeeling like an outside observer of oneselfuDescribed as feeling numb or roboticuBody or emotions feel unfamiliar DerealizationuDetachment from the external worlduEnvironment feels unreal, flat, or dreamlikeuObjects or people may appear distorteduWorld feels distant or artificial InterventionsuPsychoeducation AND stabilization & symptom management uGrounding TechniquesuSensory grounding (cold water, scents, textured objects)uSomatic awareness: breath tracking, foot-on-ground exercisesu5-4-3-2-1 sensory listinguOrientation: name 5 objects in the room, current date, colors, etc. See you next week"

content.text: Now I'll submit my critique based on the thorough review:

observations.message: EXCEPTIONAL PHASE EXECUTION: All 4 deliverables met comprehensively. The master mapping document (PHASE1_COURSE_STRUCTURE_COMPREHENSIVE_MAPPING.md) is 957 lines of meticulously organized content covering all 11 weeks with date ranges, PDF sources, learning objectives, and key concepts. Agent coordination was excellent with 6 specialized content analysts working in parallel.

CONTENT STRUCTURE MISMATCH IDENTIFIED: The existing study-site courseData.json contains GPC 415 (Behavior Disorders) content, not PSYC100. This is expected and intentional, but highlights a critical architectural decision for Phase 2: should content be incrementally replaced or fully regenerated? The JSON structure in courseData.json uses raw_content fields with embedded PDFs, while agent-generated JSON uses structured key_concepts arrays. These formats are incompatible and will require transformation logic.

INCONSISTENT OUTPUT FORMATS: Agents produced both JSON and Markdown files with overlapping content. For example, weeks-1-2-content-analysis.json contains structured data while weeks-1-2-summary.md contains narrative summaries. This duplication creates maintenance burden. Phase 2 should consolidate to single authoritative format per week, likely the structured JSON matching study-site schema.

WEEK NUMBERING AMBIGUITY: The master document correctly identifies that Week 7 and Week 12 are midterm weeks (not content weeks), but the extracted content files use inconsistent numbering (e.g., 'weeks_3-4', 'weeks_5_6', 'weeks_9_10'). Phase 2 should establish clear mapping: content weeks 1-6, 8-11 map to study-site weeks 1-6, 7-10 respectively (skipping midterm weeks).

SENSITIVE CONTENT HANDLING: Week 10 (Intelligence) includes controversial topics like racial IQ differences and the Bell Curve. The master document correctly notes 'emphasize environmental explanations' but this needs explicit implementation guidelines for Phase 2. Recommend creating content review checklist to ensure academically accurate yet non-stigmatizing presentation of sensitive psychological topics.

MISSING VALIDATION AGAINST TARGET SCHEMA: Phase 1 analyzed source PDFs thoroughly but didn't validate output against study-site's actual JSON schema (src/data/weeks/week1.json). The existing schema has 'topics' array with 'keyTakeaways', 'content' (with type: heading/paragraph/list/callout), and 'questions' array. Agent outputs don't match this structure exactly. Phase 2 will need schema transformation layer.

QUESTION BANK STRATEGY UNCLEAR: Phase 1 notes mention '15+ MCQs required per topic' and identified good quiz topics (e.g., attribution biases, Piaget stages), but no sample questions were generated. Phase 2 (Question Bank Generation) should specify: question difficulty levels, distractor quality standards, and avoidance of ambiguous questions. Recommend creating question templates for common question types (definition, application, comparison).

EXCELLENT METADATA EXTRACTION: Assessment structure (2 midterms 30% each, final 40%) and attendance policy (70% requirement) were correctly extracted from syllabus. Learning outcomes clearly documented for all 11 content weeks. Key researchers (80+), theories (40+), and specific statistics (e.g., '65% secure attachment', '37% Asch conformity') preserved with proper attribution.

PEER COORDINATION EFFICIENCY: 6 content analyst agents worked in parallel, which is excellent for speed. However, there's evidence of slight overlap in documentation (multiple agents created summary files). For Phase 2, recommend assigning agents to non-overlapping weeks with clear output file naming convention to prevent duplication.

PHASE 2 SCHEMA TRANSFORMATION REQUIRED: The gap between extracted content (concept/definition/importance structure) and target schema (heading/paragraph/list/callout) is significant. Phase 2 needs explicit transformation rules: How do 'key concepts' map to 'content' blocks? Should all concepts become callouts or paragraphs? Where do learning objectives go? This architectural decision will affect content quality and student experience.

input.summary: SENIOR DEVELOPER ASSESSMENT: Phase 1 execution was exceptional - all deliverables met with high quality. The master mapping document is comprehensive and well-organized, providing an excellent foundation for Phase 2. However, critical architectural concerns exist for implementation: (1) Output format inconsistency (JSON vs Markdown duplication), (2) Schema mismatch between extracted content and study-site target format requiring transformation layer, (3) Sensitive content handling needs explicit guidelines, (4) Missing validation against actual target JSON schema. The content analysis itself is thorough and academically accurate with proper attribution. Recommend Phase 2 starts with schema transformation design before content generation to avoid rework.
recommendations: Phase 2 should begin with explicit schema mapping document: extracted content structure -> study-site JSON schema
Consolidate to single output format per week (eliminate JSON/Markdown duplication)
Create sensitive content review checklist for controversial topics (racial IQ, mental disorders with celebrity examples, etc.)
Validate at least 1 sample week output against actual study-site schema before bulk generation
Establish clear week numbering convention (content weeks 1-11 -> site weeks 1-6, 7-10 skipping midterms)

input.message: CRITIQUE SUBMITTED: Comprehensive senior developer review completed with 10 observations covering architectural concerns (schema transformation required, format inconsistency), praise (exceptional execution, metadata extraction), and strategic recommendations for Phase 2. Key findings: deliverables fully met, but critical schema mismatch between extracted content and study-site target format needs resolution before Phase 2 implementation.
